de.tubs.cs.iti.krypto.chiffre
Class Charconvert

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--de.tubs.cs.iti.krypto.chiffre.Charconvert
public class Charconvert
extends java.lang.Object

This is a helper-class, containing some static methods for converting and handling characters in different sized character sets.
Currently, only character sets of size 26, 27, 30 and 31 are supported: 

 size = 26: 'a'-'z'
 size = 27: 'a'-'z','*'
 size = 30: 'a'-'z','ä','ö','ü','ß'
 size = 31: 'a'-'z','ä','ö','ü','ß','*'
All characters are treated case-insensitive.

isValidModulus

public static boolean isValidModulus(int m)
Tell whether the specified value is a valid (ie known) modulus.

Parameters:
m - an Integer value

ordMod

public static int ordMod(char c,
                         int modulus)
Return the numerical value of the specified character.
Although Unicode is used all over this package, we're focussing on very small moduli (26, 27, 30, 31) to keep calculating time reasonable; thus, we're effectively using our own character set.

Parameters:
c - a character.
modulus - size of the character set.
Returns:
the numerical value of the given character, adapted to a character set of size modulus.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if an invalid modulus is specified.
CharconvertException - if the character is not valid in this character set.
See Also:
chrMod(int, int)

chrMod

public static char chrMod(int n,
                          int modulus)
Return the character-representation of the specified numerical value.
Although Unicode is used all over this package, we're focussing on very small moduli (26, 27, 30, 31) to keep calculating time reasonable; thus, we're effectively using our own character set.

Parameters:
n - a numerical value.
modulus - size of character set.
Returns:
the character representing the specified numerical value, adapted to a character set of size modulus.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if an invalid modulus is specified.
CharconvertException - if the character would be invalid in this character set.
See Also:
ordMod(char, int)
